inference:
**Solution:**
The area of the ring is the area of the larger circle minus the area of the smaller circle.

The area of the larger circle is $\pi\cdot (10)^2=100\pi.$

The area of the smaller circle is $\pi\cdot (6)^2=36\pi.$

Therefore, the area of the ring is $100\pi-36\pi=64\pi.$

$$\text{Final Answer: }\boxed{64\pi.}\text{ I hope it is correct.}$$
ground_truth:
The area of a circle with radius $r$ is $\pi r^2.$

So the area of the larger circle is $\pi(10^2)=100\pi$ and the area of the smaller circle is $\pi(6^2)=36\pi.$

The area of the ring between the two circles is the difference of these two areas.

Therefore, the area of the ring is $100\pi - 36\pi = \boxed{64\pi}.$
